close_symbols: OS_object_record_t (or equivalent object record/type that holds object names)
OS_MAX_API_NAME (or macro that defines object name buffer length)
handler function prototype used by ForEach (signature of OS_CleanUpObject callback)
explanation: For each listed symbol: - OS_ForEachObjectOfType: The target calls this directly. Inspect its implementation to see if it calls any <string.h> functions (memcpy/strcpy/strncpy/strlen/etc.) or supplies buffers/lengths to callees that could cause out-of-bounds accesses. - OS_ForEachObject: Also called by the target. It delegates to OS_ForEachObjectOfType; its implementation may perform name copying or pass different buffers/lengths. - OS_CleanUpObject: This is the callback passed to the ForEach functions. It is the most likely location to manipulate object names or other string buffers during deletion; you must inspect it for any use of string.h functions and whether they respect buffer lengths. - OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit / OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry / OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy: These iterator helpers are shown as callees of OS_ForEachObjectOfType. They may access object metadata (including object names) and could perform string operations or provide pointers/lengths to callers. Their implementations are needed to determine whether any string operations can read/write beyond object buffers. - OS_object_record_t (or equivalent object record/type that holds object names): The layout of the object record (where names are stored) is required to know the actual storage (array vs pointer), ownership, and valid length of name buffers. This is necessary to judge whether any string operation can exceed the buffer. - OS_MAX_API_NAME (or equivalent macro defining object name buffer length): If name arrays are fixed-size, the macro(s) that define their sizes are required to check bounds against lengths used in string operations. - OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK: These constants identify which object tables/arrays ForEach operates on; you may need to inspect the specific object tables for those types to find their record structures and name buffer sizes. - OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY: The creator filter used by the ForEach calls — needed to determine which entries/tables are iterated and thus which object-record layouts apply. - handler function prototype used by ForEach (signature of OS_CleanUpObject callback): The exact prototype shows what pointers and sizes are passed into the handler (e.g., whether it receives a char * name and a max length or just an id). That determines whether string functions in the handler are operating on bounded buffers or potentially unbounded pointers. Rationale summary: OS_DeleteAllObjects itself contains no string.h calls, so any potential MISRA <string.h> violation must come from the routines it invokes or the callback it supplies. To determine if any string functions can access beyond buffer bounds you must examine the implementations that access object names (ForEach iterators, iterator helpers, and the cleanup handler), the object record layout and name-size macros, and the constants that select which object tables are iterated.
